column4: any idea how to make linux reset all device nodes? I only have two nics and they are detected as eth2 and eth3... I'm not sure why not eth0 and eth1
check this file --> /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules
perfect... what would be the consequences of setting no persistent names?
use /dev/disk/by-uuid/ or /dev/disk/by-label/ or /dev/disk/by-id/ .... etc
I thought of that, but my USB drives are not listed in /dev/disk/by-uuid
well from reading the man page i do not think mdadm accepts anything but dev nodes
ok thanks. That's what I found too but thought maybe there was something else I could try
maybe you can create/modify some udev rules to assing persistent dev nodes to your usb disks. that would be what you want
yes, I asked about that a while back but I was told that it was likely impossible
but that would surely make things easier
i do not see why this would be impossible,,,
actually the system I'll be using this setup on uses hotplug, not udev
mdadm is for the md subsystem and lvm2 is for the md subsystem of the kernel... and yes there is some overlapping in funcionality between the two (both can do levels of raid but dm has other uses)
is one better than the other?
i can not say i gues that all depends on what you want to do
well, ultimately I want a soft raid solution that offers the most flexibility and support
got for mdadm then
curious... why?
mdadm only does raid is more focused and widely used afaik
I notice that most distribution installers have LVM2 support - but I never see mention of mdadm
may be becouse lvm2/dm has more features (like encryption; dm-multipath; snapshot etc)
just came across EVMS as well... how does this compare to LVM2?
is it widely supported by Linux installers yet?
evms is built on top lvm/lvm2 (just an interface) and i thought it was abandoned
